title: Weaker but Larger, Dorian Lashes Florida
text:
Hurricane Dorian began whipping Florida on Tuesday after carving a slow, erratic path across the Atlantic Ocean that left the Bahamas devastated and proved maddening for emergency planners.

With winds of 110 miles an hour, the Category 2 storm churned about 105 miles east of Vero Beach, Fla., late Tuesday afternoon, moving northwest at 6 miles per hour, the National Hurricane Center said.

While the storm was downgraded Tuesday, forecasters warned the system had grown in size and that its hurricane-force winds extended 60 miles from its center.

Photos: Hurricane Edges Toward U.S. Coast After Battering Bahamas The path of the powerful storm was highly unpredictable A car sits submerged in water from Hurricane Dorian in Freeport, Bahamas, on Tuesday. Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press 1 of 19 • • • • • 1 of 19 Show Caption A car sits submerged in water from Hurricane Dorian in Freeport, Bahamas, on Tuesday. Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press

“We want people to know that even though the storm’s category has changed, Dorian is still expected to bring life-threatening storm-surge, heavy wind and rain to the area from Florida to the Carolinas over the next few days,” said Carlos Castillo, a FEMA deputy administrator.

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis said he was grateful Florida was poised to dodge the worst, when a week ago it looked like a potential catastrophe for the state.

A hurricane warning was issued for portions of the South Carolina and North Carolina coastlines.

Shifting forecasts for the storm’s path and intensity have frustrated contingency planners, who have had to adjust quickly to reposition resources. Utility crews from Nebraska that staged in Orlando ended up heading home after Dorian was downgraded and its trajectory shifted. Hospitals raced to transport backup generators to facilities that suddenly fell under the potential path.

Across Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, the American Red Cross had 170 shelters open that served 13,000 people, said Charley English, the group’s emergency management liaison. Shelters were opening Tuesday in North Carolina, he said. With those shelters, the group could temporarily house as many as 60,000 people.

No parts of Florida had a higher than 12% chance of seeing hurricane-force winds, federal data showed, but some coastal areas still were expected to face dangerous winds. While hurricanes that have been downgraded can regain strength, forecasters didn’t expect much change to Dorian’s intensity in the next couple of days.

Bahamas Prime Minister Hubert Minnis confirmed five deaths in the Abaco Islands. “We are in the midst of a historic tragedy in parts of the northwestern Bahamas,” he said Monday, adding that the government’s focus now was search, rescue and recovery. He said initial reports from the Abaco Islands were that “devastation is unprecedented and extensive.”

As many as 13,000 homes may have been severely damaged or destroyed, according to an initial assessment by the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. In the Abaco Islands, wells were likely contaminated by tidal surge, leaving the water and sewer utility in need of pumps and equipment, according to the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency.

‘We are in the midst of a historic tragedy in parts of the northwestern Bahamas,’ Prime Minister Hubert Minnis said. Photo: jose romero/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Late Monday night, officials posted a plea from emergency-management personnel and police for residents with heavy-duty equipment to help with rescue operations. U.S. Coast Guard helicopter crews continued helping with rescue efforts there Tuesday.

The hurricane was the strongest on modern record to strike the northwestern Bahamas. Scientists who have studied the impact of climate on storms have broadly concluded that warmer air and warmer water temperatures are expected to increase the intensity of hurricanes, generating storms with more rainfall and wind speed. Evidence suggests this is already occurring. One study, cited by the U.S. government’s 2018 National Climate Assessment, found the “heaviest rainfall amounts from intense storms, including hurricanes, have increased by 6% to 7%, on average, compared to what they would have been a century ago.” Scientists, however, don’t agree whether the frequency of hurricanes is affected by a changing climate.

In Florida, mandatory evacuation orders were lifted for some counties but remained in nine counties, according to the state’s Division of Emergency Management.

Flood Risk As a hurricane’s strength intensifies, so does its potential to cause flooding along the coast. A hurricane warning was in effect from Jupiter Inlet in Palm Beach County to Ponte Vedra Beach in northern Florida.

In Melbourne Beach, Fla., Vanessa Brancheau said she and her husband and three children planned to stay put in their house a half-block from the ocean. Although also under a mandatory evacuation order, she said she had faith the family would be safe during the storm, given its shift to the east.

“I’m very confident that it’s not going to get crazy,” she said.

Ms. Brancheau and her husband stocked up on food, fuel and propane. They have a battery-powered radio and board games to entertain the children—ages 10, 7 and 3—in the event of a blackout.

Eight Florida hospitals and about 110 assisted-living facilities and nursing homes evacuated ahead of Dorian’s arrival, according to state health-care trade groups. One hospital was scheduled to reopen Tuesday evening. For those that have remained open, Dorian’s strength, unpredictable path and slow progress have complicated preparations for the storm and immediate recovery.

HCA Healthcare Inc., one of the nation’s largest hospital companies, had dispatched 34 generators as of Thursday to serve as backup generators to the emergency generators already in place at HCA hospitals in Florida, said Jonathan Perlin, the company’s chief medical officer.

As Dorian’s predicted path changed, HCA made similar preparations along the new track, he said. But the company left in place many of the backup generators in Florida as forecasters warned Dorian’s path may be uncertain, he said. “Prudence dictated we keep them in Florida,” he said.

Florida Power & Light Co., which had some 17,000 utility workers ready to respond to outages caused by Dorian, said late Tuesday afternoon that it had restored nearly 70,000 outages that occurred as Dorian’s outer bands of severe weather affected Florida’s east coast. Most were caused by trees and other vegetation falling on equipment and power lines, the company said.

States of emergency were in effect in Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia.

South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster issued mandatory evacuation orders for coastal residents in eight counties. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp ordered an evacuation of six coastal counties starting at the same time. North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper ordered a mandatory evacuation of all the state’s barrier islands as of early Wednesday.

Shifting Paths Forecasts of Dorian’s track have fluctuated in the past week, making it difficult to predict where, or if, the storm will make landfall in the U.S. 5-day probable track area Projected path as of 5 p.m. Tuesday Atlantic Ocean 5 p.m. Aug. 29 Storm location at 5 p.m. Tuesday Aug. 27 forecast 5 p.m. Aug. 31 Dorian’s actual path 5 p.m. Aug. 27 5-day probable track area Projected path as of 5 p.m. Tuesday Atlantic Ocean 5 p.m. Aug. 29 Storm location at 5 p.m. Tuesday Aug. 27 forecast 5 p.m. Aug. 31 Dorian’s actual path 5 p.m. Aug. 27 5-day probable track area Projected path as of 5 p.m. Tuesday Atlantic Ocean 5 p.m. Aug. 29 Storm location at 5 p.m. Tuesday Aug. 27 forecast 5 p.m. Aug. 31 Dorian’s actual path 5 p.m. Aug. 27 5-day probable track area Projected path as of 5 p.m. Tuesday Atlantic Ocean 5 p.m. Aug. 29 Aug. 27 Storm location at 5 p.m. Tuesday Dorian’s path 5 p.m. Aug. 31 5 p.m. Aug. 27

Mr. Kemp reversed eastbound lanes on Interstate 16 on Tuesday for more than 100 miles from Savannah west to Dublin. Mr. McMaster reversed eastbound lanes of Interstate 26 to Charleston for more than 100 miles on Monday, saying he knew changes in traffic patterns could be inconvenient but it was critical to ensure safety.

Dorian took a toll on U.S. industries while still miles away in the Atlantic. Seaports from Miami to Charleston, S.C., have closed or plan to, including Port of Charleston, S.C., one of the busiest ports on the East Coast. Meat giant Tyson Foods closed its Jacksonville, Fla. beef-processing plant Tuesday as a cautionary step, a company spokesman said.

Orlando International Airport closed through late Wednesday afternoon, while Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International was slated to reopen at noon Tuesday, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. JetBlue and Spirit canceled a quarter of their scheduled flights Tuesday.

Authorities to the north were also closely tracking forecasts for Dorian. In Massachusetts, the state’s emergency management agency said Dorian could bring tropical storm conditions to Nantucket, Cape Cod and other coastal areas as early as Friday.

Share Your Thoughts What would you do if you lived in central coastal Florida? Join the conversation below.

Write to Arian Campo-Flores at arian.campo-flores@wsj.com and Erin Ailworth at Erin.Ailworth@wsj.com
description: Hurricane Dorian began whipping Florida on Tuesday after carving a slow, erratic path across the Atlantic Ocean that left the Bahamas devastated and proved maddening for emergency planners.
